00001 /**
00002  *  @file matrix.h
00003  *
00004  *  @brief  2D matrix manipulation functions
00005  *
00006  *      Generic implementation of bidimensional matrix
00007  *  calculus. It contains functions to allocate memory
00008  *  space and, by this time, elementary matrix calculus.
00009  *
00010  *  All matrix operations should be done using the interfaces
00011  * provided. If efficiency is a must, you may try defining
00012  * MAT_OPTIMIZE and see if the alternative code provided with
00013  * its shortcuts may increase speed.
00014  *
00015  *  In general, and during development in particular, you are
00016  * advised to ALWAYS define MAT_PARANOIA to enable bounds
00017  * checking. This may slow down some operations, most notably
00018  * accessing individual matrix elements but will reduce the 
00019  * possibility of errors passing unnoticed. Only if you are
00020  * really confident that you don't have errors in your code
00021  * should you venture to risk undefining MAT_PARANOIA.
00022  *
00023  *  @pre        stdio.h
00024  *  @pre        math.h
00025  *  @pre        stdlib.h
00026  *  @pre        bits/nan.h
00027  *  @pre        portable.h
00028  *
00029  *
00030  *  @note    Estoy hasta los cojones.
00031  *          Today (1 - oct - 1988) is my father's birthday
00032  *      and here I am like a dumb loser.
00033  *
00034  *  @bug    There must be some bug in the matrix allocation code for
00035  *      the optimized implementation.
00036  *
00037  *  @todo   Debugging the MAT_OPTIMIZE implementation
00038  *
00039  *  @todo    I intend to add functions for the solution
00040  *      of systems of equations, manipulation of eigenvalues
00041  *      and eigenvectors.
00042  *
00043  *  @see    mat_test.c      Is an auxiliary module with
00044  *      the test code of these functions used to debug this
00045  *      module (last time everything went OK).
00046  *
00047  *  @see    mat_housekeep.c To learn how to create/destroy matrices.
00048  *
00049  *  @author    José Ramón Valverde Carrillo.
00050  *
00051  *  @version    2.0
00052  *
00053  *  @date   11 - february - 2004    v2.0
00054  *
00055  *  @date    1 - october - 1988     Last modification of v1.0
00056  *
00057  *      COPYRIGHT:
00058  *          © YoEgo.    Since I have no cash, I can't
00059  *      register this (nor do I believe I should). So
00060  *      this module is left in the PUBLIC DOMAIN.
00061  *          It is furthermore forbidden its use for
00062  *      commercial purposes unless I get a share on
00063  *      the profits.
00064  *          I say.
00065  *                                              YoEgo.
00066  *
00067  * $Id: matrix.h,v 1.1 2004/03/05 18:26:06 jr Exp $
00068  * $Log: matrix.h,v $
00069  * Revision 1.1  2004/03/05 18:26:06  jr
00070  * Initial revision
00071  *
00072  */

00075 /** @def MAT_PARANOIA enable additional checking at the cost of efficiency */
00076 #define MAT_PARANOIA
00077 
00078 typedef double real;
00079 
00080 /** @typedef struct matrix matrix
00081  *
00082  *  @brief A two-dimensional matrix type.
00083  *
00084  *  This type should be used as a black box. All accesses to matrix
00085  *  elements should be done through the functions provided in mat_access.c
00086  */
00087  
00088 /** 
00089  *  @brief Implementation of a 2D-matrix
00090  *
00091  *  A matrix A is a set of values grouped as a table arranged by
00092  *  rows and columns: a matrix m x n (rows x columns) is
00093  @f[
00094  A = \pmatrix {
00095         a_{11} & a_{12} & \cdots & a_{1n} \cr
00096         a_{21} & a_{22} & \cdots & a_{2n} \cr
00097         \vdots & \vdots & \ddots & \vdots \cr
00098         a_{m1} & a_{m2} & \cdots & a_{mn} \cr }
00099  @f]
00100  * where a<sub>ij</sub> are the elements of A (i = 1..m, j = 1..n)
00101  * Vectors are matrices with only one row or column: they only need
00102  * one subindex.
00103  *
00104  * Sometimes it may be convenient to consider special rows or columns:
00105  *
00106  *  R<sub>i</sub>(A) -- row i.
00107  *
00108  *  C<sub>j</sub>(A) -- row j.
00109  *
00110  * @note Please, note that all subindexes are offset at one (1)
00111  */
00112 typedef struct matrix {
00113     int rows;       /**< number of rows */
00114     int cols;       /**< number of columns */
00115     real **values;  /**< matrix values arranged as an array of real vectors */
00116 } *matrix;
00117 
00118 #define MAT_NOMEMORY    (-1)    /**< ERROR: not enough memory */
00119 #define MAT_BOUNDSCHECK (-2)    /**< ERROR: during bounds checking */
00120 #define MAT_SINGULAR    (-3)    /**< ERROR: matrix is singular */
00121 #define MAT_NOTSQUARE   (-3)    /**< ERROR: not a square marix */
00122 
00123

00129 extern status mat_free(matrix mat);

00136 extern int mat_cols(matrix mat);
00137 extern real **mat_values(matrix mat);
00138 extern real *mat_row(matrix mat, int row_number);
00139 extern real mat_element(matrix mat, int row, int col);

00147 extern status mat_identity(matrix mat);

00162 extern status mat_multiply(matrix prod, matrix fact1, matrix fact2);
00163 extern status mat_scalar_product(matrix scprod, matrix mat, real lambda);

00173 extern status mat_invert(matrix B, matrix C);
